title: prep_app
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.1     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

melbourne_house_data <- read_csv('MELBOURNE_HOUSE_PRICES_LESS.csv')

Rows: 63023 Columns: 13
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (8): Suburb, Address, Type, Method, SellerG, Date, Regionname, CouncilArea
dbl (5): Rooms, Price, Postcode, Propertycount, Distance

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

melbourne_house_data <- 
  melbourne_house_data |> 
  mutate(Full_Date = as.Date(Date, format = "%m/%d/%Y"))

melbourne_house_data

# A tibble: 63,023 × 14
   Suburb   Address Rooms Type    Price Method SellerG Date  Postcode Regionname
   <chr>    <chr>   <dbl> <chr>   <dbl> <chr>  <chr>   <chr>    <dbl> <chr>     
 1 Abbotsf… 49 Lit…     3 h     1490000 S      Jellis  1/04…     3067 Northern …
 2 Abbotsf… 59A Tu…     3 h     1220000 S      Marsha… 1/04…     3067 Northern …
 3 Abbotsf… 119B Y…     3 h     1420000 S      Nelson  1/04…     3067 Northern …
 4 Aberfel… 68 Vid…     3 h     1515000 S      Barry   1/04…     3040 Western M…
 5 Airport… 92 Cly…     2 h      670000 S      Nelson  1/04…     3042 Western M…
 6 Airport… 4/32 E…     2 t      530000 S      Jellis  1/04…     3042 Western M…
 7 Airport… 3/74 H…     2 u      540000 S      Barry   1/04…     3042 Western M…
 8 Airport… 1/26 H…     3 h      715000 SP     Nelson  1/04…     3042 Western M…
 9 Albanva… 1 Jack…     6 h          NA PI     hockin… 1/04…     3021 Western M…
10 Albert … 18 Mil…     3 h     1925000 S      Cayzer  1/04…     3206 Southern …
# ℹ 63,013 more rows
# ℹ 4 more variables: Propertycount <dbl>, Distance <dbl>, CouncilArea <chr>,
#   Full_Date <date>



melbourne_house_data |>
  group_by(Regionname) |>
  summarize(count = n())

# A tibble: 8 × 2
  Regionname                 count
  <chr>                      <int>
1 Eastern Metropolitan       10396
2 Eastern Victoria             564
3 Northern Metropolitan      16781
4 Northern Victoria            556
5 South-Eastern Metropolitan  5212
6 Southern Metropolitan      17559
7 Western Metropolitan       11717
8 Western Victoria             238



melbourne_house_data |>
  group_by(Suburb) |>
  summarize(count = n())

# A tibble: 380 × 2
   Suburb         count
   <chr>          <int>
 1 Abbotsford       183
 2 Aberfeldie       111
 3 Airport West     238
 4 Albanvale         37
 5 Albert Park      185
 6 Albion            99
 7 Alphington       110
 8 Altona           161
 9 Altona Meadows    85
10 Altona North     211
# ℹ 370 more rows






melbourne_house_data |>
  group_by(Suburb, Type) |>
  summarize(count = n()) |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = Type, values_from = count)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Suburb'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 380 × 4
# Groups:   Suburb [380]
   Suburb             h     t     u
   <chr>          <int> <int> <int>
 1 Abbotsford       114    14    55
 2 Aberfeldie        81    11    19
 3 Airport West     152    35    51
 4 Albanvale         36    NA     1
 5 Albert Park      168     7    10
 6 Albion            58    17    24
 7 Alphington        78    15    17
 8 Altona           102    21    38
 9 Altona Meadows    77     2     6
10 Altona North     159    36    16
# ℹ 370 more rows






melbourne_house_data |>
  group_by(Suburb, Type) |>
  drop_na(Suburb, Type) |>
  summarize(mean_price = mean(Price, na.rm = TRUE), med_price = median(Price, na.rm = TRUE),mean_rooms = mean(Rooms, na.rm = TRUE), med_rooms = median(Rooms, na.rm = TRUE))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Suburb'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 918 × 6
# Groups:   Suburb [380]
   Suburb       Type  mean_price med_price mean_rooms med_rooms
   <chr>        <chr>      <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>
 1 Abbotsford   h       1222216.   1200000       2.66       3  
 2 Abbotsford   t       1018900     931000       2.57       2.5
 3 Abbotsford   u        681011.    658000       1.95       2  
 4 Aberfeldie   h       1590831.   1545500       3.53       4  
 5 Aberfeldie   t       1090000    1150000       3.18       3  
 6 Aberfeldie   u        498222.    411000       1.74       2  
 7 Airport West h        836992.    815000       3.26       3  
 8 Airport West t        677600     695000       2.74       3  
 9 Airport West u        601826.    588500       2.45       2  
10 Albanvale    h        508737.    506000       3.31       3  
# ℹ 908 more rows



melbourne_house_data |>
  group_by(Region = as.factor(Regionname)) |>
  summarize(mean_price = mean(Price, na.rm = TRUE), med_price = median(Price, na.rm = TRUE),sd_price = sd(Price, na.rm = TRUE)) 

# A tibble: 8 × 4
  Region                     mean_price med_price sd_price
  <fct>                           <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>
1 Eastern Metropolitan         1071837.    990000  415250.
2 Eastern Victoria              689369.    670000  220135.
3 Northern Metropolitan         823720.    715000  416156.
4 Northern Victoria             643082.    590000  269381.
5 South-Eastern Metropolitan    846235.    780000  359621.
6 Southern Metropolitan        1373222.   1230000  829559.
7 Western Metropolitan          800516.    700000  372547.
8 Western Victoria              412026.    400000  122663.



melbourne_house_data |>
  group_by(Regionname = factor(Regionname), Type = factor(Type)) |>
  summarize(mean_price = mean(Price, na.rm = TRUE), med_price = median(Price, na.rm = TRUE),sd_price = sd(Price, na.rm = TRUE),mean_rooms = mean(Rooms, na.rm = TRUE), med_rooms = median(Rooms, na.rm = TRUE), sd_rooms = sd(Rooms, na.rm = TRUE)) 

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Regionname'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 23 × 8
# Groups:   Regionname [8]
   Regionname  Type  mean_price med_price sd_price mean_rooms med_rooms sd_rooms
   <fct>       <fct>      <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>
 1 Eastern Me… h       1148132.   1070000  417619.       3.61         4    0.913
 2 Eastern Me… t        916497.    875000  246330.       3.20         3    0.674
 3 Eastern Me… u        703789.    670000  219087.       2.46         2    0.596
 4 Eastern Vi… h        694976.    672000  219898.       3.60         4    0.787
 5 Eastern Vi… t        565500     597500  168635.       2.83         3    0.718
 6 Eastern Vi… u        469357.    447000  110928.       2.67         3    0.492
 7 Northern M… h        905373.    787000  436730.       3.21         3    0.802
 8 Northern M… t        713081.    676500  235115.       2.60         3    0.618
 9 Northern M… u        574629.    521500  280870.       1.96         2    0.672
10 Northern V… h        644728.    589500  272174.       3.58         3    0.761
# ℹ 13 more rows


Measures of Association between two numeric variables: price and number of rooms using pairwise complete observations.

melbourne_house_data |>
  group_by(Regionname = factor(Regionname), Type = factor(Type)) |>
  summarize(correlation = cor(Price, Rooms, use = 'pairwise.complete.obs')) |>
  arrange(desc(correlation))

Warning: There was 1 warning in `summarize()`.
ℹ In argument: `correlation = cor(Price, Rooms, use =
  "pairwise.complete.obs")`.
ℹ In group 11: `Regionname = Northern Victoria` `Type = t`.
Caused by warning in `cor()`:
! the standard deviation is zero


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Regionname'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 23 × 3
# Groups:   Regionname [8]
   Regionname                 Type  correlation
   <fct>                      <fct>       <dbl>
 1 Eastern Victoria           t           0.788
 2 Eastern Victoria           u           0.677
 3 Eastern Metropolitan       t           0.616
 4 Southern Metropolitan      u           0.599
 5 Western Metropolitan       u           0.550
 6 South-Eastern Metropolitan u           0.549
 7 Eastern Metropolitan       u           0.526
 8 Western Victoria           u           0.519
 9 Western Metropolitan       t           0.469
10 Southern Metropolitan      h           0.467
# ℹ 13 more rows
